job_title: Design & Analysis Engineer in Everett, WA
pros: Flexible schedule, lots of sick leave, educational benefits are great. You can learn about anything. Most people are willing to teach about their work. There's tons of opportunity. If you're good at networking you can find interesting assignments.
cons:
Management faces no consequence for bad decision making. I've seen projects years late and overbudget and the managers just get moved to new projects. Engineering has to deal with all the problems as result of their terrible planning. 
Good ol' boys club as you get higher in the management structure. Technical fellows are mostly old men with egos who typically add limited value. All these people are the backbone of the company and contribute to things being way late and overbudget. It doesn't take that much digging to see multiple Boeing products that were way late and overbudget. (787, Tanker, 777X, CST-100).

review_title: The Big Name Is Not Worth It
job_title: Manufacturing Engineer in Cecil Field, FL
pros: Well known in the industry so it looks good on a resume, mechanics are intelligent and always willing to help you learn, parking lot is close to the entrance, snack machines, close to the Space Coast so it's easy to drive down for an interview when you want to leave this site, pay for schooling and certificate programs
cons: Management is run by out of touch MBAs that never explain decisions leading to resentment among the employees. PTO is plentiful but frowned upon when taken. Work-life balance is stressed but they won't work with your life schedule on flexing hours even though they claim it, it's all talk. The shift starts at 6am and is in the middle of nowhere so you have to drive far to get there. Extremely inconsiderate when giving annual reviews; if you had a bad few weeks before the review, they'll weigh that more than previous 50 weeks even if they were above average weeks. If you address problems within the process specifications/standards that leave room for subjective interpretation, you will be judged and dealt with when you 'mess up' for interpreting wrong. You bring up these issues and they rarely, if ever, get resolved. They promote and hire people for positions that they aren't qualified to fill. Managers are yes-men and bow down to managers of other groups every time and will never stick up for you. Rules and policies are enforced arbitrarily at the whim of the quality department - 'what can we nit-pick this month and cause rejections on?' Not many opportunities at this site to move around and grow. You'll be stuck at your position if you take a role at this site. You're essentially a computer, same work every single day. You get reprimanded for leaving your desk even though that's part of your job to inquire about work on the vehicle. You get snitched on for little things like taking a break after working for a constant 2 hours of knocking out work. The management does not seem to understand the day-to-day operations of the engineering roles on site. Managers are in to favorites and giving them raises, bonuses, promotions, etc. Managers never address the lack of training. Managers show that they don't consider what is told to them from employees regarding process decisions and day-to-day operations. It's a lot of talk around here and no action. And the little action they do take is inconsiderate of the employees and inefficient. Total pump and dump culture - get your year and leave.

job_title: Site Reliability Engineer in North Charleston, SC
pros:
* Great Benefits including generous PTO, Holidays, and Education Reimbursement
* Tons of Learning opportunities
* Multiple paths for advacement
* With the right manager, you get to do the work you enjoy
* Great Work/Life balance
* Being a global company, there are opportunities to work anywhere in the US and around the world
cons:
* A manufacturing company first and IT company second
* Due to the size of the company, there is a ton of bureaucracy that can get in the way of productive work
* Also due to the size of the company, and how old it is, there is a constant conflict between IT personnel who are fine with using older, company made technologies and time consuming processes and IT personnel who want to adopt newer technologies that reduce server overhead and share data easier over API's.
* While benefits are great, overall pay could be better
* 737 MAX issues have tainted the companies image and it will take a lot of trust to get it back

job_title: Quality Assurance Inspector- 737 MAX in Seattle, WA
pros: An easy job to cruise through life with (if that's what you want)...
cons:
The list is exhaustive and has changed my views on OEM aerospace manufacturing and Boeing products as a whole. I will never fly on another 737 MAX aircraft after what I saw.

-the worst quality culture I've ever experienced...anywhere.
-management are completely inept and promoted to a level of incompetence. They violate FAA regulations, OSHA regulations, and IAM contract requirements without thought and to make production times/rates.
-speaking of the IAM union, they are great at taking your $120 a month before taxes, but do little to nothing to protect your job, or make sure the management follows the rules. "Best union Boeing could buy."
-dangerous level of incompetence by people from non-mechanic jobs "promoted" to A&P level mechanic jobs that haven't been properly trained.
-little to no training on anything that remotely reflects your position and the inspections you'll carry out. They don't even Gen Fam you on the aircraft you are supposed to inspect, like an airline would before you are allowed to touch it.
-witnessed individuals "rubber stamping" entire inspections off when they haven't even left their chair.
-witnessed all kinds of defects from the factory that were made worse by their trained "mechanics."
-as an A&P, you will be expected to sign off on multiple repairmen that don't have A&Ps, and you will also be moved (by order) to locations where you have no responsibility or training, and expected to sign off there, violating FAA regulations. 
-COVID was a joke to this company, they hid under their military side of the company as a Government contractor to maintain essential worker status and forcing commercial employees to work within tight confines...and people died. 
-zero upward mobility, assumed, because I knew too much and would not be a "yes" man.
-pay and benefits have not kept up with WA cost of living, as a matter of fact, you'd have a tough time affording an Apt.

There's your dirty laundry, think twice about joining this company as an A&P, and if you do, make sure you have experience to compare, so you don't dangerously put your A&P license and ethics at risk. Take these as a word of advice from someone who has worked for their customers and other manufacturers.

review_title: Not what it once was and getting worse
job_title: Programmer Analyst II in Hazelwood, MO
pros:
-Benefits are Great and are the main reason Boeing gets away with how they treat employees
-Cool Products if you're enough to work on them
-Exciting work, if you are in the right place
cons:
-You are a number, most importantly, a cost
-Projects can lose funding in a snap if someone up top doesn't see the benefit
-Constant fear of being laid off (see above...)
-Certain organizations, if not most, involve work on legacy systems and technologies that should have been retired decades ago but no one wants to devote budget to technical debt.
-The only way to get promoted or a raise (even more so in 2020) is to switch teams or leave the company and come back. Bonus points if you want to be executive as they only come externally.
-The company doesn't do much to retain and hire the best talent so many of the good resources are on the way out if they aren't stuck with Boeing LTP or RSU golden handcuffs
-Upper management is in a constant state of leaving the company or moving to a different role leaving a Boeing employee with a solid understanding of management's strategy extremely rare.

review_title: Avoid, unless you have high tolerance for bureaucracy and corporate BS
pros: Fair compensation; nice 401(k) match; good opportunities for training; education reimbursement; there are *some* interesting jobs, but good luck getting one.
cons:
The company has a very low bar for its workforce: you'll work with some good folks, but also a lot of rocks. 

With very few exceptions, engineering positions DO NOT involve creative engineering work and are primarily focused on navigating the internal bureaucracy. If you're an engineer who likes being on the phone, going to meetings, and managing foreign offices and suppliers doing the creative work, then you may like it here.

Management turnover is atrocious. Managers are constantly moving between different work groups, which causes enormous disruption.

Engineering excellence takes a back seat to cost (it didn't used to be that way).

review_title: Only good if you want to trade hours of your life for salary and nothing more
job_title: Systems Engineer in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
I left Boeing before the recent Financial Difficulties and Stock crash. However, before I left, it was stable. You would have to completely mess up on an unimaginable scale before suffering any consequences.

Many people who start there do end up working until retirement. Therefore, it is still a good place if your only motivation from a career is a salary and literally nothing else.
cons:
For any people still early on in their careers, working here can be a trap. This is especially true for any software related fields. The technologies used are often out of date and rarely used by outside companies It feels that Boeing floats on it's name and position as a military contractor more then any actual competitive advantage. In addition, the skills will only be useful to a few very specific applications, leaving you will little to gain for any future career growth.

As for internal growth. Promotion is often based mainly on Seniority and politics. Productivity is rarely recognized and even less so rewarded. This has resulted in very low motivation and morale within the company and a "slacker" culture. Delays are frequent, often expected. Due to this, there are frequently days where I was paid to essentially keep a chair warm and little more. All this combined makes it hard to care, as the low-motivation across the company is infectious and often soul draining. 

Management often feels detached, as managers only speak with other managers for the most part. I spoke with my manager a total of 3 times during my time there. Once when I was hired, once during my end of year review, and once when I left. Maybe as a result of this, I spend a good chunk of my time working on Initiatives that are very vague and that I don't see any real application for. Projects are often created to follow vague motivations and are abandoned when completed.

review_title: The Big Name Is Not Worth It
job_title: Manufacturing Engineer in Cecil Field, FL
pros: Well known in the industry so it looks good on a resume, mechanics are intelligent and always willing to help you learn, parking lot is close to the entrance, snack machines, close to the Space Coast so it's easy to drive down for an interview when you want to leave this site, pay for schooling and certificate programs
cons: Management is run by out of touch MBAs that never explain decisions leading to resentment among the employees. PTO is plentiful but frowned upon when taken. Work-life balance is stressed but they won't work with your life schedule on flexing hours even though they claim it, it's all talk. The shift starts at 6am and is in the middle of nowhere so you have to drive far to get there. Extremely inconsiderate when giving annual reviews; if you had a bad few weeks before the review, they'll weigh that more than previous 50 weeks even if they were above average weeks. If you address problems within the process specifications/standards that leave room for subjective interpretation, you will be judged and dealt with when you 'mess up' for interpreting wrong. You bring up these issues and they rarely, if ever, get resolved. They promote and hire people for positions that they aren't qualified to fill. Managers are yes-men and bow down to managers of other groups every time and will never stick up for you. Rules and policies are enforced arbitrarily at the whim of the quality department - 'what can we nit-pick this month and cause rejections on?' Not many opportunities at this site to move around and grow. You'll be stuck at your position if you take a role at this site. You're essentially a computer, same work every single day. You get reprimanded for leaving your desk even though that's part of your job to inquire about work on the vehicle. You get snitched on for little things like taking a break after working for a constant 2 hours of knocking out work. The management does not seem to understand the day-to-day operations of the engineering roles on site. Managers are in to favorites and giving them raises, bonuses, promotions, etc. Managers never address the lack of training. Managers show that they don't consider what is told to them from employees regarding process decisions and day-to-day operations. It's a lot of talk around here and no action. And the little action they do take is inconsiderate of the employees and inefficient. Total pump and dump culture - get your year and leave.

job_title: Quality Assurance Inspector- 737 MAX in Seattle, WA
pros: An easy job to cruise through life with (if that's what you want)...
cons:
The list is exhaustive and has changed my views on OEM aerospace manufacturing and Boeing products as a whole. I will never fly on another 737 MAX aircraft after what I saw.

-the worst quality culture I've ever experienced...anywhere.
-management are completely inept and promoted to a level of incompetence. They violate FAA regulations, OSHA regulations, and IAM contract requirements without thought and to make production times/rates.
-speaking of the IAM union, they are great at taking your $120 a month before taxes, but do little to nothing to protect your job, or make sure the management follows the rules. "Best union Boeing could buy."
-dangerous level of incompetence by people from non-mechanic jobs "promoted" to A&P level mechanic jobs that haven't been properly trained.
-little to no training on anything that remotely reflects your position and the inspections you'll carry out. They don't even Gen Fam you on the aircraft you are supposed to inspect, like an airline would before you are allowed to touch it.
-witnessed individuals "rubber stamping" entire inspections off when they haven't even left their chair.
-witnessed all kinds of defects from the factory that were made worse by their trained "mechanics."
-as an A&P, you will be expected to sign off on multiple repairmen that don't have A&Ps, and you will also be moved (by order) to locations where you have no responsibility or training, and expected to sign off there, violating FAA regulations. 
-COVID was a joke to this company, they hid under their military side of the company as a Government contractor to maintain essential worker status and forcing commercial employees to work within tight confines...and people died. 
-zero upward mobility, assumed, because I knew too much and would not be a "yes" man.
-pay and benefits have not kept up with WA cost of living, as a matter of fact, you'd have a tough time affording an Apt.

There's your dirty laundry, think twice about joining this company as an A&P, and if you do, make sure you have experience to compare, so you don't dangerously put your A&P license and ethics at risk. Take these as a word of advice from someone who has worked for their customers and other manufacturers.

review_title: Not what it once was and getting worse
job_title: Programmer Analyst II in Hazelwood, MO
pros:
-Benefits are Great and are the main reason Boeing gets away with how they treat employees
-Cool Products if you're enough to work on them
-Exciting work, if you are in the right place
cons:
-You are a number, most importantly, a cost
-Projects can lose funding in a snap if someone up top doesn't see the benefit
-Constant fear of being laid off (see above...)
-Certain organizations, if not most, involve work on legacy systems and technologies that should have been retired decades ago but no one wants to devote budget to technical debt.
-The only way to get promoted or a raise (even more so in 2020) is to switch teams or leave the company and come back. Bonus points if you want to be executive as they only come externally.
-The company doesn't do much to retain and hire the best talent so many of the good resources are on the way out if they aren't stuck with Boeing LTP or RSU golden handcuffs
-Upper management is in a constant state of leaving the company or moving to a different role leaving a Boeing employee with a solid understanding of management's strategy extremely rare.

review_title: Avoid, unless you have high tolerance for bureaucracy and corporate BS
pros: Fair compensation; nice 401(k) match; good opportunities for training; education reimbursement; there are *some* interesting jobs, but good luck getting one.
cons:
The company has a very low bar for its workforce: you'll work with some good folks, but also a lot of rocks. 

With very few exceptions, engineering positions DO NOT involve creative engineering work and are primarily focused on navigating the internal bureaucracy. If you're an engineer who likes being on the phone, going to meetings, and managing foreign offices and suppliers doing the creative work, then you may like it here.

Management turnover is atrocious. Managers are constantly moving between different work groups, which causes enormous disruption.

Engineering excellence takes a back seat to cost (it didn't used to be that way).

review_title: Only good if you want to trade hours of your life for salary and nothing more
job_title: Systems Engineer in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
I left Boeing before the recent Financial Difficulties and Stock crash. However, before I left, it was stable. You would have to completely mess up on an unimaginable scale before suffering any consequences.

Many people who start there do end up working until retirement. Therefore, it is still a good place if your only motivation from a career is a salary and literally nothing else.
cons:
For any people still early on in their careers, working here can be a trap. This is especially true for any software related fields. The technologies used are often out of date and rarely used by outside companies It feels that Boeing floats on it's name and position as a military contractor more then any actual competitive advantage. In addition, the skills will only be useful to a few very specific applications, leaving you will little to gain for any future career growth.

As for internal growth. Promotion is often based mainly on Seniority and politics. Productivity is rarely recognized and even less so rewarded. This has resulted in very low motivation and morale within the company and a "slacker" culture. Delays are frequent, often expected. Due to this, there are frequently days where I was paid to essentially keep a chair warm and little more. All this combined makes it hard to care, as the low-motivation across the company is infectious and often soul draining. 

Management often feels detached, as managers only speak with other managers for the most part. I spoke with my manager a total of 3 times during my time there. Once when I was hired, once during my end of year review, and once when I left. Maybe as a result of this, I spend a good chunk of my time working on Initiatives that are very vague and that I don't see any real application for. Projects are often created to follow vague motivations and are abandoned when completed.

review_title: Solid company with major challenges ahead
job_title: Product Specialist in North Charleston, SC
pros:
-Boeing has cool projects: xwing drones at disney world, wifi on international space station, air force 1, osprey heli/plane to name a few
-Name recognition-very few companies can match Boeing on brand/plus Boeing is always in the news
-The scale of the work needs to be seen to be appreciated (the Everett factory, for instance)
-You will meet brilliant people who have solved complex and difficult problems
-You can literally do anything at Boeing-IT to medical to astronaut to manufacturing, Boeing runs the gamut for jobs
-Good 401k match and benefits plan
-I was able to spend a morning trying out our commercial flight simulators by nothing more than sending a well worded email to the right person
-Boeing will pay for your education (undergrad/grad etc...)
cons:
-Like most big companies, siloed communication and politics can really get in the way of getting work done
-To the earlier point, Boeing culture rewards people who don't communicate with others. Heads down and compartmentalizing helps get the work done and reinforces bad habits of those who don't listen to teammates. The 737 MAX program is a prime example.
-Sometimes projects are so big that it's hard to understand what your value to the company is, and if it is explained, it's not done very well (probably because the person explaining it doesn't understand it either).
-In general, information/help can be found, but you have to look far and wide to find it, so don't expect much assistance
-If you don't like working for a weapons manufacturer, Boeing is #2 in the world.
-Involuntary Layoffs happen somewhat regularly, and with the state of COVID and commercial aviation things will be bad for awhile.
-In general, Boeing has switched from making airplanes to making money-which shows in the stock price (up) and the product quality (down).
